review_title: Best place to work in Atlanta!
pros: Great team environment, wonderful managers, and good benefits

pros: The pay, the schedule flexibility, and the employee benefits. The focus on teamwork is excellent at this hospital. We had such an amazing team on our floor. The new RN internship program was also a great experience to go through. Quality patient care.
cons: Patient satisfaction here is HUGE. I definitely understand what it means for ratings and what not, but it sometimes gets in the way of providing care. Patients are made to feel like this a 5 star hotel instead of a hospital...Nurses end up running around trying to fetch all kinds of things to please patients when they could be providing care, charting, or helping a fellow nurse. It's a little messed up. Our unit was almost always short staffed so we were often forced to accept more patients than we needed to. The ratio was supposed to be 1:5 at most but we would sometimes go up to 1:6. It didn't happen ALL the time but when it did, it was very stressful and it felt unsafe. Also, If you do the RN internship program you have to sign a 2 year contract. If you break it immediately after the internship you have to pay over $4000! It's prorated the longer you stay during those 2 years. That's a big decision to make because you never know what will happen in life.

review_title: Poor management in the Business Office, Patent Financial Services, and Oncology Business Operations areas.
pros: Northside Hospital is known in the metro Atlanta area for their excellent maternity and neonatal clinical care. They are also fast growing in the community cancer care arena.
cons: The organization is seriously behind the times with regard to ongoing employee, and leadership development and training. I worked in two of the PFS aligned areas over five years; both areas were perpetually understaffed with entry level employees and supervisors. Often staff were expected to work overtime, while Coordinators, Managers, Directors, and VPs enjoyed leaving each day on time, taking leisurely lunches, and ample PTO. When the areas did well, management was rewarded handsomely, but the worker bees reaped little in comparison. Sadly, a healthy work-life balance is nonexistent. Beware of bullying bosses at every level of the corporate structure - upper management is completely disconnected from their staff, and stay so wrapped up in playing wasteful political games, that they find themselves putting out and covering up fires, that could have been avoided altogether.

pros:
Northside Hospital is a wonderful place to work!  The nurses I work with are some of the most hard-working and caring individuals I have ever known.  We have great relationships with the ICU mid-levels and physicians, and they welcome and value our input. The staff is great, and I feel that the leadership team also welcomes and values what we have to say.  With that being said, high quality, safe and compassionate patient/family centered care is always at the forefront. This is certainly a pro, in my opinion.  The team values all of this highly and works tirelessly to promote patient and staff safety and satisfaction.  They also encourage effective communication among employees.  NSH offers many opportunities for continuing education and certification.  The unit works toward implementing different quality initiatives & this is beneficial for our patients.  Yes, there are tough days, but the comradery is great. I love that we come from all different places in life (age, gender, race, religion, etc.), but we call eachother a "family."  We even do fun things together outside of work :)

*supportive staff
*good benefits 
*competitive pay 
*high patient/family and staff satisfaction
*educational opportunities 
*incentives for extra shifts $$$$
*general ICU - we see everything! great learning experiences
cons:
*traffic (at times), but that's Atlanta for ya!  working 7a-7p or 7p-7a generally helps you dodge it though :)
*documentation system can be tough, but they are working on it!

Nurses sitting on there behinds while pts are falling because the techs are swamped with the max load of pts so if a pt had to go to the bathroom and the techs were all busy and you asked a nurse to do it they would say they were busy or it’s not my job, yes busy doing nothing, the fall score on our floor was 90%.... omg and the self scheduling was a joke to say the least, my manager would lie about holiday tracks, she would change your holiday track to meet her needs without even letting you know. If you put in your schedule in the computer, you most for certain can bet that your whole schedule will be changed and moved around.... the focus is not on the pts it’s on filling the rooms, probably why they lost their contract with one of the major physician groups,  and this is just the tip of the ice burg... job_title: CCA (Clinical Care Associate) in Cumming, GA
pros:
I have worked in so many different environments and in many different positions. Thus far, my experience with Northside has been nothing but the best. The work life balance is amazing, the employees are fantastic, and there is an overwhelming sense of compassion for the patients. I have had countless patients explain to me that Northside is the best place they've ever gone for medical treatment, and I completely understand why. As far as working here, I have compiled a few of the pro's into a list:

-Wonderful benefits program
-Fair, competitive pay
-Beautiful Facilities 
-Great work environment
-High employee moral 
-Opportunities for advancement
-Yearly raises (with good marks on your yearly evals)
-Satisfactory risk reduction programs
-Competent HR/employee support
-Emphasis on patient satisfaction (which is the most important thing if you are in healthcare for the right reasons) 
-Countless learning opportunities
cons:
There are very few issues I've seen from working here, mostly to do with timelines during the hiring process:

-Onboarding process takes a while, but it isn't confusing or difficult to understand. If you have issues, there is ALWAYS someone to help.
-Initial hiring process takes a while (but i promise that patience pays off!)
-TONS of initial hire paperwork (staying organized is paramount)

pros: Good benefits and supportive management
cons: Constantly short-staffed and no hazard pay for COVID

pros: Great work atmosphere in Atlanta
cons: Employee Parking could be better

pros: Get work place ever in Ga.
cons: Parking could be better for employees

review_title: Faith Wheeler, MBA BSN RN CNOR
job_title: Quality Programs Coordinator, Ambulatory Surgery Centers in Sandy Springs, Fulton, GA
pros:
1.  The Surgical Services Department at Northside Hospital offers many unique growth opportunities and has numerous departments for a variety of opportunities within the same healthcare system.
2.  With locations in Atlanta, Forsyth and Cherokee, it is easy to find a location that will fit your career location desires.  There are numerous outpatient surgical center departments, ambulatory surgical centers,  and  the traditional inpatient settings for career opportunities. 
3.  Northside Hospital is very committed to growth in meeting the patients' needs and is constantly investing in new technology and improvements within Surgical Services.
4.  Northside Hospital Surgical Services has a very committed and patient focused Quality and Education Department  dedicated to excellence and meeting the staffs' educational needs to provide the best care to our patients in Surgical Services. 
5.  Northside Hospital offers a great pension plan, as well as the opportunity to invest more through a 403b.
cons: The traffic in the Sandy Springs area is the only con!  However, there are opportunities for various shift that can help employees avoid the rush hours.  Additionally, there is road expansions in the works in the Sandy Springs area to help with this congestion.

pros: Pay, personal desk, time off request,
cons: Management, unorganized, PTO, breaks time

job_title: Registered Nurse Emergency Department in Canton, GA
pros: They're hiring.  But it's only because they're hemorrhaging talent all over the place because the scheduler and immediate management are like Larry, Moe, and Curly falling over each other trying to run a department with hands-off intimidation rather than logic and rationale.
cons: They treat educated and skilled healthcare professionals like teenagers at a fast food restaurant.  Their scheduler is wholly inadequate and the managers are incompetent.  They purposely mislead during interviews about the availability of specific schedules and other important details and then lock you into a contract that you have to buy your way out of to escape.  If you want to work in an ER that can improve your career, steer clear of this place: the HR department won't even deal with you in a civil manner when they find out you work in the Cherokee facility.

pros: Experience, level up, and growth
cons: Management and salary, customers, nurses

job_title: Unit Clinical Secretary in Sandy Springs, Fulton, GA
pros: Flexible Hours and Great Benefits!
cons: There isn't any advancement opportunities.

pros: Work environment, prestige, staff ratios
cons: Traffic, management may differ, busy

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Knoxville, TN

cons: management is poor and unprofessional

review_title: Okay place- can be difficult to advance- but generally better than other area hospitals
job_title: Medical Case Manager in Canton, GA
pros: good pay, benefits, co-workers, commute- new facility (it sparkles)
cons: Poor communication- unrealistic expectations - over burden of capable people and lack of accountability for those less capable. Nurse favored environment- if you’re not one, advancement is tough- narrow minded leadership- the location is growing fast with the usual lack of staff to compensate- the organization favors pleasing patients and family over staff support ( floor staff, physicians, etc) . Mixed messages about goals- ‘reduce length of stay, but the ED physicians cannot be challenged on who they recommend for admission- even a splinter gets admitted)

job_title: Emergency Medical Technician in Canton, GA
pros: The pros are the coworkers are the best you could ask for. For the most part they stick together
cons: Administration doesn't care about anything but numbers and dollars

review_title: Northside Hospital is a Fantaastic organization to work with
pros: Northside Hospital is like no other organization I have worked for.  Now approaching my 10 year anniversary I can say without a doubt that if you are looking for an organization that cares about its employees, patients and patient families, This is the organization to be with.  Teamwork is the foundation, service excellence is the fiber and exceptional patient care and outcomes are our results.
cons: I do not have any cons to share at this time.

pros: I have been working at Northside Cherokee as a Nurse Resident for only 2 months, but so far I am absolutely loving it! I am on the 6th Floor, General Surgery & Extended Recovery Unit. My co-workers are very approachable and they have welcomed me so warmly to their team family. Not once have I felt like no one will answer my questions or help me out with patient care if I am overwhelmed. Not only have my co-workers been wonderful, but management also. My clinician and supervisor are understanding, as well as encouraging. The patient load (4-5 for days, 5-6 for nights) and pay rate ($24.50/hr as a nurse resident, $27.50+ after graduation) are reasonable. Northside also offers tuition reimbursement for any employee who wants to further their education. Northside has Employee Appreciation Day each year -- this year, the hospital rented out all of Six Flags for a night and opened it up for Northside Employees only. Tickets (meal included) and parking were free! I am truly thankful to be working at a hospital like Northside!
cons: So far, I have not come across any downsides of working at Northside. In a few weeks, the computer system will be switching from McKesson to Cerner Millennium, but this is a normal process for any hospital.

pros: People are friendly, hours are set
cons: Need more money for the work we do

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Scientist in Atlanta, GA
pros: It's close to a hospital and has free parking.
cons: Working in the Molecular department was like working in a concentration camp.  I was told multiple times when a test run failed that I alone was killing patients, and my supervisor directly sent our names to the doctor. The supervisor and director always told us how poor employees we were and tried to turn each employee against one another.  They refuse to listen to ideas by employees and then when an idea is approved they send an email out stating they came up with this idea and are wanting us to follow it. There is ageism and sexism that happens here. I had an exit interview with the director and she called a fellow employee in and asked why I was leaving, that I used them for a job, and I was not a very good scientist anyway. I called HR multiple times and they said it was not a priority and that maybe they would look into it. If I followed up, HR said that the director or supervisor said that I was the problem, so I needed to grow up.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Cherokee, Cherokee, GA
pros:
Northside cherokee in particular is awesome to work for because of my coworkers. Everyone truly gets along and works together as a team to help each other out. Our physicians are another reason I love working here. Every Dr. whether its a specialist or not all take their time and are very thorough with each patient. Our CEO, Billy Hayes is the most friendly, approachable and professional boss to work for. You can tell he truly cares about our work environment and wants the best for everyone at this hospital.  

They reimburse you for furthering your education which encourages you to obtain more knowledge while increasing your opportunities for new positions within northside!
cons: My drive is far but its worth it for the patients in this community, my coworkers, the doctors and northside in general. There are of course the occasional implementations that make you double document or make an easy path more complicated. However, it is all because of research and things that prove a new way is safer, more efficient and proven to be better for patients care.

review_title: Some of the best days of my nursing career!
pros:
•The entity cares about you as an employee!

•My joy to nursing returned with my employment to Northside Cherokee. 

• They allow you the ability to do what you are passionate about. 

• The ancillary services are amazing! 
   •PT/OT/ST see the patients everyday! 
   • The radiology dept. is calling me for my patients test       before I know they have it ordered most of the time! 

 • STAT labs are back STAT (AMAZING!)

• My co-workers are the definition of TEAM! 

•Health insurance is so much better and affordable.
cons:
• We cannot wear holiday scrub tops like Wellstar allows from Thanksgiving till the new year. (That’s a big bummer.)

• No employee concierge service (like Wellstar)

• Not on EMR yet... this is the biggest con and was almost a deal breaker for me to work for them. Then they are moving to Serner in December 2018, instead of to EPIC like the rest of the big metro Atlanta hospital systems. Which would be so much better for access and fluid movement of patient information across the hospital networks!

review_title: Hard to grow with this company
pros: Job security,  company has been around a long time.
cons: Extremely hard to grow with this company.  Promotions not based on knowledge or what is best for the department but  if the manager has any personal grievances that have absolutely nothing to do with the job or not. Extremely political and not ethical. The pay is well below other hospitals in surrounding areas. Loyal employees not taken care of at all..new hires with very little to no experience paid substantially more than people who have been with the company for years

pros: No pros unless you like no life
cons:
Very demanding the management staff is very disrespectful they do not care about the safety of the employee or having a work/life balance.  Not flexible at all when it comes to time.  Thinks everyone wants to be at work at 5a every day not willing to budge to have later start times or shifts of 9a or 10a.  Thinks it is funny when some of the staff got stuck overnight on the hwy during the last ice storm.  Instead of ensuring the staff left in time to make it home they force employee's to stay to get bills out the door.
Northside isn't very good with self-pay patients either.  They don't want uninsured patients at their facilities, so stay away if you don't have money to pay.  Northside doesn't pay fair either, they will hire someone off the streets paying more money to them instead of paying their current workers on the same scale.  The business office has a very high turn over and is very stressful due to the demands and the show of disrespect by management.

review_title: Management Heavy, Does Not Invest in Workforce
pros: Excellent pharmacy discounts on OTC medication
cons:
As former management at NSH, I can attest to the fact that they do not train their managers to treat employees as anything greater than cogs in their performance machines. 
Each department keeps diligent track of certain metrics (selected by management) from which they're judged each month. The problem here is that many of these metrics are superfluous to departmental goals or even standard of care. 
We're pushed hard to collect meaningless data points to appease a wall of VPs that have all been at the hospital for decades. The VPs are out-of-touch, have unrealistic expectations of employees (cutting breaks, mandatory weekends, etc), and are too busy fluffing one anothers egos to realize the morale of the place is crumbling beneath them. 
The only thing that keeps this place going is the naivety of the new hires due to the CONSTANT TURNOVER. 
I put in my two weeks and my Director begged me to stay, offered a raise, AND offered a promotion, and I just couldn't do it. This place is toxic.

pros: The hospital has a great reputation in the community, there's a pension plan, and it's a big enough system that you can move laterally once you're part of the system.
cons: Leadership's focus is completely off.  If you want evidence based practice, look elsewhere.  Leadership are nit-picky about simple things, but allow major patient care issues to fall through the cracks.  We still use paper charting and handwritten orders - the hospital likes its docs too much to require them to use computerized orders.  Northside's focus is on keeping its physicians happy, and they really couldn't care less about their nurses.  Understaffed, under appreciated, and poorly managed.  They treat their nurses like grade school kids who need scolding. Physicians have access to resources like UpToDate and Krames, but nurses do not. Also, while there are plenty of opportunities to move laterally around the hospital system, there is almost zero upward mobility.

pros: I love my job and my hospital. The culture is amazing! There's a sense of caring that trickles down from the top, to the employees and finally to the patients. It's a great place to work.
cons: The low rating I gave is because I am incredibly disappointed that although we are getting a new computer charting system, we are keeping our old, outdated paper charts as well. The paper chart is a constant source of confusion and stress on every unit. Nurses, secretarys and managers are often seen huddled around the chart attempting to decipher hand written orders for important procedures, labs, and medications. Nurses can rarely read MD progress notes leaving us uninformed and confused regarding plans for care.  Orders are missed regularly because they are written on the incorrect page, or the chart is not"flagged", creating delays in care.  It is a dangerous, time wasting, confusing system.

pros:
Northside is a growing company that values their employees. This hospital offers a pension and has given merit increases every year for the past 19 years.
Northside takes pride in Clinical excellence as well as Service excellence at the bed side. Northside Hospital encourages employees to further their education and climb the ladder. They offer tuition reimbursement and loan repayment program.
Northside also pays close attention to Nurse/Patient ratios.
Cherokee has a great team approach when we have a  high census. Everyone in the hospital communicates and works with each other for the best patient experience.
cons: Northside is a growing Company and a lot of patients want to be cared for at the Cherokee Campus. Sometimes we are low on Patient rooms but we always find a way to take care of the patients needs. Unfortunately, we have to use a stretcher in the hallway to care for the patient but the Nursing care stays the same.  Our beautiful new hospital will help with the volume we have been experiencing.

job_title: Staff RN I in Canton, GA
pros:
I’ve heard horror stories about new nurses not being welcomed or accepted. This is not the case at Northside. From day one everyone was very welcoming and friendly. No one is ever too busy to answer a question or lend a hand. 
Our charge nurses are all amazing and super helpful as well. 
The manager of our unit is great and she always makes sure that if day shift is getting food provided by the hospital as a thank you that those of us on night shift also get food.   
 Northside is also big on education. There are thousands of classes that we can sign up to take. Not only are these classes free, we also get paid to attend. Travel expenses to attend these classes are also reimbursed if the class is offered at a different campus. 
 The nurse residency program was great and very helpful. 
 Charting has gotten much better now that we use Cerner
cons: On very rare occasions the patient to nurse ratio is 5:1, but thankfully that has only happened a few times in the 1.5 years I’ve worked here.

pros: I have been an employee of Northside Hospital for 7 years and I have to say that it is a good place to work. The pay is good, benefits are good, and I feel that I am contributing on my job. I was in the Business Office for five of these years and it was a big difference moving onto another department. Northside does have some of the nicest executives you ever want to meet! No really, they do!!! Middle management is questionable.
cons: It is very competitive and it is too many people, leads, supervisors, managers, etc. Also, raises are a joke.

review_title: Parking is a nightmare for employees.
pros: Benefits, environment, good resources, nice facility
cons: PARKING! Northside seriously needs to reconsider the employee parking situation. Due to recent changes, there is not enough parking for employees. I arrived to work 20 minutes early and ended up 10 minutes late because there was not enough employee parking in the mornings. I had to leave the employee parking deck and re-enter on the visitor parking deck and PAY to park for the day. It is ridiculous! Would not recommend Northside to anyone looking for a stress free Parking environment. Parking should not be such an issue. I already have an hour and a half commute, so leaving a half hour early just for parking should not have to be on my agenda. Not having a place to park and causing employees this amount of frustration makes them feel undervalued.

review_title: Medical Assistant/Surgery scheduler/tTriage nurse, answer phones, make appointments etc.
job_title: Most Duties In the Office Except Billing in Cumming, GA
pros: Great reputation and known for the great benefits. Also there are some phenomenal doctors.
cons: I feel underpaid for all of my job descriptions, being crossed trained, experience and dedication to help keep the great reputation. Because we are a specialty off campus, it's difficult to talk to anyone above the practice coordinator without email and feel like it's confidential. Medicine has become corporate and that makes me sad. Patients are treated like numbers. Employees are confused esp if there has been a merge.

review_title: Northside is my Pride and Joy
job_title: Clinical Nursing Informatics Clinician in Atlanta, GA
pros: Northside Hospital is my pride and joy because you have the opportunity to grow and growing in your carrier gives you the  knowledge and opportunity to be your best while providing your services and  care to our patients. It is the place to be because I have worked for NSH for 22+ years and still loving it.
cons:
There are more pros working at Northside that you never have the opportunity to look for the cons. I always try to see the positive. That keeps me grateful. 
I had to crack my brain for a little while to think about the cons because that is what this section is all about. Is driving for about a total of 60miles in traffic every morning to Northside and every afternoon/evening back home a con? I guess the answer is yes, but because of the love I have for Northside hospital, I have never really sat down to analyze that. Just grateful for the opportunity I  have for being in the NSH Team.

review_title: High Hopes and Excitement turned into Disappointment
pros: Great teamwork,  Amazing patients from diverse backgrounds, Extended network of Knowledgeable Physicians,  Talented staff that care about patient care, Awesome benefits,
cons:
Pre-employment departmental issues negatively affected my orientation period.  The changes and inconsistencies during orientation made it difficult to establish a routine while learning the Northside Health System and departmental norms. I did the best I could given the circumstances, but I became increasingly frustrated with my experience, as I had high hopes when I received the job offer.  After major self-reflection and evaluation, I decided the position and department wasn’t a good fit. 

After the submission of my 2-week resignation, I had several Benefit & HR Related questions that I was confused about because I was unable to ask my department.  I submitted inquiries via AskHR, after which I received written and phone replies that were polite up until my last phone call with them.  Even though I didn’t have a favorable first experience as a Northside employee, I considered applying for a position in the future with a different department since the system has a large network.  Not anymore ☹

pros: I work with a great group of people that feel like family. I am with them more than my family. We work as a team to provide the  best care to our patients . Northside is always offering continuing education classes to advance our knowledge and provide the most up to date changes happening in the medical field. They encourage furthering your education
cons: There is a different hospital  chain more dominant in the area where I live. I would love to see Northside  expand further west to serve  those that live and that are patients closer to their home

job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros: Gain a lot of experience. Meet some great people.
cons: Pay. Long hours. Strict dress code, most business casual attire sold in stores is not accepted. Volunteer work is expected and used to be taken into consideration with our reviews. Management is very shallow and condescending. Most take themselves too seriously because of their pay grade. Daycare employee rates are a JOKE. So good luck rushing through traffic to get your kid after you were pressured to stay later than need be. Not worth the stress. Just take the experience and get out.  You will not be promoted, that promotion you worked hard for will go to somebody's relative, friend etc that they know outside of work.

pros: I've worked at Northside for little under a month now. I have had a wonderful experience so far! One of the things that drew me to this company were the overwhelmingly positive reviews and I can say they weren't wrong! The recruiting and onboarding process were involved, but I had helpful specialists along the way to answer any questions that came up. Everyone within my department has been open and friendly. In fact, I was shocked when my first week was spent meeting with all of the leaders and learning more about them and their teams. In the past, I've spent weeks guessing which names went with which faces. At Northside, I can name each person in my department, which is no easy feat! After such a positive beginning, I have no doubt my time here will be amazing.
cons: The onboarding process was a bit overwhelming, with multi-step processes and different deadlines for different pieces. Overall I had helpful guidance, but it was somewhat stressful prior to actually beginning the job.

review_title: Phenomenal growth and opportunity at Northside Hospital when economy is good.
pros: The opportunities for education and training are plentiful and encouraged for all levels of staff. Managerial benefits were generous and appreciated.  Constant growth and plans for the future infected the employees with optimism.  During good economic times there is no better place to work in healthcare Atlanta market.  Administration friendly and open to ideas.  Terrific non-profit organization.
cons: As a non-profit, the economic recession of 2008 hit Northside hard and there were many rounds of layoffs for a two year period--through early 2011.  Clinical staff was kept of course, but hundreds of long term employees including Directors and Managers in non-clinical roles lost their jobs.  Positions were eliminated and those job duties spread to other existing lower paid staff members.

pros: Northside has a good benefits package (medical/dental/vision insurance, retirement, pension after 5 years, PTO, various optional services at low or no cost) and a good work environment. Leadership is typically understanding and willing to help with any problems you may have. The culture here is comfortable and people seem to get along. Sometimes the workload can be heavy, but I don't feel like the company places the weight or the blame on the workers like some of my other jobs have done. The PTO accumulation is generous and one of my favorite parts of the job. I like being able to take a day off if I need to take care of my children and not have to worry about how it will affect my finances. Periodic time off keeps everyone happy and more productive.
cons: Northside may be growing a little too quickly. They have handled it well so far but I do worry about how work will be affected in the future. Several departments have had mandatory overtime for an extended period.

pros: it's a pretty good company to work for overall. Good pay, good benefits. I am happy with my location and hours and my job is very rewarding.
cons: The management has had a lot of turnover and it just gets worse. They either tell you what you want to hear to or just flat out ignore your concerns and do nothing about it. The management is unprofessional and very unfair. Employees are obviously picked on if your not liked and those that do a bad job and make a lot of mistakes don't get any reprimand. Our scheduling department is the worst I've ever seen. There is never any praise or compliments for those who do a good job, it's just expected and non stop discipline for petty things.

pros: Decent benefits, pension, paid time off.
cons: Company is not very sympathetic towards employees with children who may need to call out, or when life just happens in general. the company allows only four unexcused call outs a year, after that you get a write up and anything with a notice less than two weeks is considered unexcused. management is very secretive and also plays favoritism. it doesn't matter how long you've been around or how hard you work, if you're not a favorite you can kiss a promotion good bye. the pay is pretty mediocre and I feel it could be better. I've been with this company for 10 years, have moved to three different departments, I am highly educated and a promotion has never happened for me and probably never will. I personally am looking into moving on from the company as a whole. This company may be better for people with a clinical background, but for non clinical, in my personal opinion it's awful.

review_title: Worst Company I ever worked for (Behavioral Health)
pros: High Salary, decent benefits, some great people
cons: Terrible management. The people in charge and supervisors have no business in their job roles. The culture is one of fear and reprimand. You can never do anything right. You are always punished, berated, and I dare say it is emotionally abusive. They cause PTSD for the same people there to treat it in the patients. The work load is unbearable and unreasonable. There is no reward for hard work and all accomplishments are quickly forgotten. The supervisors are unstable and like to cause drama. They treat the patients terribly. They will berate them, have favorites, and make highly unethical decisions. There is no understanding of the client or the therapists lives. There is a lot of gossip and everyone will stab you in the back. No job security with people constantly quitting or getting fired for no reason. They micromanage every aspect of you life. Imagine having to take 15 minutes PTO because you will be late from traffic! It's so degrading.

pros: I found the culture to be appealing. Those that are non-managers are the backbone and heart of Northside. They're also genuine and have integrity. Those at the manager level and up are incompetent puppets on a string.
cons:
1) Compensation - Seems to be a morale killer when the highest paid CEO in hospital-based care in Atlanta is at Northside (source: AJC). Don't expect a 3% merit raise each year, either. 
2) Promotion - It is non-existent unless you are a puppet. If you have the right credentials and experience, your best option for advancement is to leave after a reasonable time. 
3) Experience - Employment decisions are not based on experience, but what school the applicant went to or some type of minimally-applicable experience someone had to the job. 
4) Systems - As Northside is expanding, an investment should be made into an ERP. Efficiency could be made a lot better.

review_title: No place is perfect, however if you want to feel important work here!
pros: This company really does seem to care about the employees compared to the other entities in the area. Such as Wellstar. You will feel valued and appreciated. The culture at Cherokee is very different then the other campuses. Billy Hayes makes it a great hospital. Warm and inviting.
cons: They really could have purchased EPIC computer system to be uniform with all the other large entities in the area. It's a good system and it would have helped streamline employee onboarding since most employees are coming from EPIC systems it would have cut back on the training required for these new employees.

pros:
Flexible schedule
Great floor nurses and PCTs
cons: We just got a new manager and she is doing a great job fixing things up.  However, certain dayshift charge nurses and clinicians are bullies to the majority of the nurses (not just new grads), and only a couple of the charge nurses offer any help even though we are drowning.  Charge nurses will stand outside the patient's door listening to make sure nurses do their "5 P's" throughout our shifts.  I've even heard of a couple of nurses being written up for forgetting to ask about one of the "Ps."  It seems like patient satisfaction is held to a higher standard than patient safety is on this particular unit.

review_title: NorthSide a good place to work
pros: We are blessed to have our jobs ,not laid off and be able to work from home. I am glad that they got to see that we can be trusted to work from home and are giving us the tools we need to be successful!
cons: All departments need to be accountable and do their jobs. They can make you not hit your goal. More training needed!!!! You should not have to address the same issue with a department 3-4 times before it gets resolved. Training is key.

review_title: Happy to be a part of Northside Hospital
pros: I love that I have had the opportunity to learn a lot of new things after being in AR for 26+ years. I very much appreciate my Supervisor and Manager always willing to get on the phone and assist when needed. I also very much appreciate Northside Hospital going through so much to allow DM to work from home which allows me to help out more with other assignments due to not having the commute of 80 miles per day. I also very much like the team working together to help out on aging accounts regardless of circumstances.
cons: Pressure of feeling like you can't spend enough time on those accounts that need extra attention.

pros: Staff works well together, Try to keep floors well staffed, Will work with you on your schedule as you can fill it out, opportunities for growth
cons: Difficult and time-consuming charting system, Only 4 call outs allowed, management is a little unorganized, Are not always well staffed even though they try to be, Parking in employee parking lot takes a while to get inside work.

pros:
I love my job with Northside and they have provided me opportunity for advancement.  It is a great place to work for the most part.  I have referred several friends and family members here.  
Great name in the community.
Family type environment
Care and concern for the patients
cons:
The employees that work at the hospital and the employees of Physician Practices owned by Northside are treated very differently.  The employees of the Physician Practices are more like a disassociated family member. 

Also, NSH as a whole tends to focus more on keeping the "bad employees" than trying to retain those that actually produce.

pros:
Northside hospital was my first job as a nurse and I am still here 15 years later!
I had so many opportunities to grow and learn that I will be forever grateful. I started as  bedside nurse, then preceptor, then clinician, then clinical nurses specialist, then a nurse practitioner and now I manage 2 departments for the system.
Northside "raised me" as a nurse and as a leader. I always had the support of my leadership to get to the next step, much like  parents would do for their kids.
"A lifetime of care" is not something Northside offers only for the patients. I am a first hand receiver of that care.
cons: One con about working for Northside? I won't have time during my work life to take on all the opportunities available for nurses within our organization..

review_title: Working full time at NSHC while attending Nursing school (Junior).
pros: I genuinely love working for NSHC. I work night shifts. At first, I felt a little uncomfortable because I didn't know anyone, but they treated me like a family member from the start and I immediately felt belonged. I love our night crew and we work together as a team. Working as a PCT, you might here an there find a nurse that is not caring but its not something usual, so majority of nurses I have worked with never looked down on me, they helped me and did their best to fulfill their duties.If you are working on MED/SURG unit and Stella or Rachel happen to be your Supervisor, then you will have the most pleasant working experinece you would ever have in your career.
cons: I can't recall any cons except nursing in general is long working hours and a demanding job, so be prepare what you getting into.

review_title: Northside is an amazing place to work!
pros: The nurses truly have a voice and are able to help improve processes. More so than anywhere else I’ve worked as a nurse.  The pay is very competitive, and you’re rewarded for good performance, furthering your education, and staying with northside. They really like to grow and keep their employees.
cons: Nursing is a hard job. It isn’t easy anywhere you go, and I think we all knew that when we signed up. I really can’t think of any cons specific to the northside system. I work at the cherokee campus, and we are constantly growing, so there are the associated growing pains and changes. But the transitions are generally handled well, and short lived. When a new unit opens, we may be temporarily short staffed to help support the new unit. But we’re constantly hiring, and for me, as long as we’re working to fill the holes, running short to support the house temporarily, isn’t so bad.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Cumming, GA
pros: Northside Forsyth is everything they say they are. They are all about the patient and teamwork. The department I work in are full of people that love their jobs and it shows in everything they do. You're treated with professionalism, you're spoken to with manners, and they make you feel like you've been a part of this family unit all your life. The director and supervisors are NOT hiding in their office. They are engaged, happy, and very hands-on. Our director cares about the patient, the team, and you can see that from a mile away. I feel very privileged to work with a team that sets the standard to go above and beyond, but is right there with you helping you to achieve it. I feel at home finally! I could never say enough good things about Northside. Their commitment to the patient and the team speaks for itself.
cons: Nothing that I have seen.

pros: Growing hospital system, opportunities if the environment is right for you
cons: During your HR orientation, they talk about mentoring programs, a culture designed to keep employees for their careers. None of it happened for me. I asked about it. Nothing. This was my first foray into healthcare systems. Culture embraces lack of professionalism. Email go without responses. Calls go unanswered. If you come from a business background and assume professional courtesy, be wary.

pros:
1. Good medical insurance with three options. Choosing the high deductible option for single, you only have to pay about $2/paycheck (2 weeks)
2. Flexible schedules for evening and night shift are available
3. Base pay rate is competitive
4. Retirement plan includes pension and 403(b).
cons:
1. They don't pay any weekend differential while most of other hospitals do. The shift differential is also lower than other places. No bonus for employee. 
2. You cannot cover your spouse's medical insurance if they can get their own from their employer. If you have a dependent, the cost for medial insurance is very expensive.
3. Although they combine two plans together for retirement, the benefit isn't necessarily better than other places. For pension, if you make 50,000 annually, after 25 years, they'll pay you close to 14,000/year when you get retired. 403(b) plan only matches 50% of the first 4% you contribute.

pros: Great pay, good leadership,
cons: I don't like the fact that every job that I have applied for within the past three years I have never been considered. I have the credentials, possess the skills and knowledge base and I feel as though I've been overlooked. Several of my cohorts feel  the exact same way and when you call to speak with a recruiter,  no further information is given to help. I truly like Northside and I feel as though there are so many amazing opportunities to grow but how can we if not given the proper treatment of being considered like "family". I wish all the recruitment process would change and they truly look at the transfer request thoroughly, consider the candidate, and actually give a call to say exactly why you are not considered for a open position within your scope of practice.

pros: The Service Excellence! No where else have I had this level of standards required from me. Treating your patients, visitors and each other with high requirements promotes quality care and a very good environment to work in. In addition Management is always looking for staff to grow and excel at NSH. Opportunities are available for those who are willing to invest what it takes to learn and succeed in a Leadership role at Northside Hospital! Preceptor opportunities, Mentor, Charge and our new NEXT program are all just a few opportunities available to the staff RN.
cons: Atlanta traffic! I would say this is definitely the biggest concern most folks have if their commute is from the suburbs as Atlanta traffic is a daily trial and MARTA doesn't cover many of the areas employees need.

pros: Because of the Hospital's phenomenal growth, career development opportunities at Northside are almost limitless.  I've particularly enjoyed the many Leadership training classes that are offered here and I never cease to be impressed with both the quality of instruction as well as the quality of my classmates.  There is a very strong culture of excellence at Northside that can be seen throughout all the departments and you can't help but be proud to be a part of this organization.
cons: The commute is really the only downside to this job.  My drive home (~ 23 miles) can take up to 1.5 hours.  Parking here is also not the best but plans are underway to add a large parking deck that will greatly help this situation.

pros: You will receive a pay check!
cons: I'm sure this isn't the first time someone has written a statement concerning the racism you will experience at Northside Hospital Cherokee. If your not WHITE you will be viewed as a second class citizen/worker no matter what degree or clinical experience you may have. Do yourself and your family a favor and stay as far away from that place as you can. It's one of the most racist places I have ever  worked as a Professional Nurse. Racism is alive and well at Northside Hospital Cherokee beware! But if your white with blonde hair, you will be welcomed with open arms. Most blacks who have worked there have the same sentiment! I've even heard it said that they hire black just so they can get government money such as Medicaid and Medicare but they are definitely not welcome.

pros: I love this hospital! I am a tenured healthcare employee and I have worked several jobs over the last 15 to 20 years. I must say that this is one of the best companies that I have been so fortunate to be a part of. My supervisors and co-workers are great. My supervisor, Laleisa (supervisor) Cornelius has been extremely helpful and encouraging. She works hard and the entire department does the same. My coworkers have been wonderful and never hesitate to assist me when I need help. We have overtime and we all go the extra mile to help our patients.
cons: None at the present time.

review_title: Disrespect of the professional nursing staff by many of the managers.
pros: Northside Hospital in Atlanta is know as "The Baby Factory" in  the US.  With Northsdie Hospital on your resume, a nurse is almost guaranteed a position at another hospital.  This aspect trumps the disrespect to the professional nursing staff shown by many of the managers.
cons: The employee insurance is not up to par with other hospitals in the area.  There is no set schedule to your work schedule, and there are many "call-off" days.  The only means of food for the employees on the night shift is McDonald's, sack lunch from home, or delivery.

pros: Northside Hospital system is a great place to work as a whole!  Northside Cherokee is my home campus and I love it here.  We have a close-knit team and every department is committed to collaboration for excellent patient care.  Leadership strives to create a culture of safety for both patient and staff.  We strive for a spirit of true teamwork!
cons: All organizations have opportunities for improvement and I can say we are no different.  The difference is the approach to embrace these opportunities and improve care as we learn from each occurrence or suggestion from patients and staff.  The commitment to excellence and continuous improvement from NS Leadership is unparalleled

pros: Northside Hospital - Cherokee is very family oriented and a fun place to work.  My coworkers are my family and have been right by my side through personal issues as well as health problems.  For the most part every one shows professional and common courtesy to others.  Billy Hayes, the CEO, strongly encourages an environment where service excellence meets outstanding personal service.
cons: There are those few people who are not as professional as others, but you have that everywhere.  There is far less of it here than other places I have worked.

review_title: Great pay, but no work/life balance
job_title: Senior Lab Computer Analyst in Sandy Springs, Fulton, GA
pros:
Great retirement/pension
Competitive pay: the highest paying in Atlanta
Friendly staff: the employees are what make this hospital great
Beautiful facilities
cons:
No work life balance; you have to almost beg for time off.  Managers micro-manage instead of lead.
HR policies do not match the prestige that this hospital promotes.  
PTO policy and Maternity leave are not good.  You have to use your PTO for holidays even if your department is closed.  
For a hospital that brags about delivering more babies than any other in the southeast, they have a terrible maternity leave policy.

pros: Great benefits, and that’s about it.
cons: Extremely stressful environment not just for employees, but for patients as well. Everyone knows NS have an extremely high turnover rate. Outpatient-especially Dekalb location-is a nightmare. Existing staff is extremely toxic but management protects them at all costs since they’ve been there for a long time. An extraordinary amount of paperwork. Techs, if you value your sanity, DO NOT work at Northside Hospital. Run. Fast.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Cumming, GA
pros:
- Great Benefits such as PTO, Insurance, Scheduling.
- Hiring process is very easy and helpful. 
- HR is such a big help for anything work related.
- Bi- weekly pay
- Retirement plan/ account
cons:
- Pay is very low for Techs. If you are experienced then it helps a little. 
- All floors have their way of doing things so be prepare for a lot of learning. 
- Management on the Oncology department does not handle situations very well. They do not talk to the individuals if there are any problems directly affecting them and their work place. 
- All departments are guilty of not confronting any behavioral issues between staff. There is a lot of disrespect between nurses to other nurses, techs to techs, or even techs to nurses on all floors.

job_title: Nurse in Sandy Springs, Fulton, GA
pros: Great benefits, great pay! They are one if the few hospitals who are still offering annual raises and offer health benefits at an affordable price for families.
cons: The benefits and the pay are all that Northside has to offer. If you go to HR with an issue, they break your trust. It is all about who you know if you want to advance. Many leadership positions are given to people with no experience what so ever! HR never handles complaints against a superior, they simply sweep it under the rug and tell you to suck it up. The atmosphere is not friendly but rather very tense and sometimes hostile!

job_title: Talent Acquisition Recruiter in Atlanta, GA
pros:
The culture is outstanding here.  We have been rated number one in Atlanta for years as the preferred hospital and I really feel Northside's values exemplify service, kindness and support.  We try really hard to make good matches for new employees to help them transition here.

Growth and opportunity

Competitive salaries, rewards for service skills, RN Levels program, tuition assistance

Free Northside Pension plan is rare- I've been here over 13 years so it is great to see my retirement grow in addition to Social Security. It's  a great reward for committing to Northside!

The people .  We are a community based hospital growing and with a strong reputation in the community.  We take that role seriously.
cons: None I can think of.  We are growing but it seems to be steady and thought out.

pros: I got a call shortly after applying to the residency program for new grad RNs at Northside Hospital. The recruiter, Liz Wright, was SO helpful and sweet. She took the time out of her day to go through what to expect during the interview process, which really leaves you feeling prepared/less nervous when you do go for the interview. My interview was a panel interview with all of the nurse clinicians of my floor. Each was extremely professional, and you can tell they really try to select the right candidates for the job. And then I got the job, and have just completed my first week here at Northside. So far I love it! Definitely the best hospital to work for in Atlanta in my opinion, ESPECIALLY if considering any mom/baby position.
cons: I have nothing bad to say about Northside Hospital.

pros: There is a great sense of collegiality in my department, and I love the spirit of the people I work with. In such a large organization it would be easy to not see people, but at Northside there is a great sense of family and a recognition of diversity embraced by collegiality.
cons: The size of the organization makes it difficult to ensure that the values that I have enjoyed here and are part of the ethos of the hospital system, are equally present in all department and areas of the hospital.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: Discount in the cafeteria.  Retirement pension.
cons: Management is terrible, only interested in the people who follow blindly.   Knowledge and experience not rewarded. Not willing to give the resources to do the job properly.   Extreme micromanaging and very cliquish. Benefits mediocre and   You have to use your PTO for holidays even if you work a normal work week and your department is closed.  Degrees over experience.  Does not acknowledge or reward going the extra mile.

pros:
* team environment promotes good morale
* recent increase in base pay to be on par with other hospitals
* recent advancement opportunities with Next program
cons:
* offer no maternity/paternity leave. Employees have to take their own PTO for two weeks and then short term disability which only pays half of base pay for 4 weeks.  For the premiere baby hospital of the southeast and the top 20 employers of the US (according to Forbes), they severely lack in this area. They really should consider offering some maternity paid time off. 
* McKesson charting system is very counter intuitive and promotes double charting.

pros:
Employees receive training on a consistent basis.     Northside provides training for individual job requirements as well as,  safety,  infection control,   proper communication,   language assistance for those patients that have language barriers.    We also receive training on non-discrimination practices.    
Benefits are very good.     Competitive salaries, insurance,  employee assistance,
403B,  pension plan,  recognition for tenure.
cons: There are times when it feels that the chain of command is so great that no one is hearing you.

job_title: Physician Practice Integration Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: Management is very supportive.   They don't say one thing and do another, they truly model and practice the methods they would like for others to follow, both within the department and within the Northside community.  They are inspiring to work for and their example really makes you want to support them in all they are trying to accomplish in their own careers and for the department.  Added bonus:  Best work/life balance I have ever had in any job.  It is such a blessing and worth even more than pay.  Could not be happier with the benefits, too!
cons: Lack of visibility on Accounts Payable has been difficult, but the team has been very helpful and they are working on an initiative to change this, so it won't be a drawback much longer!

review_title: Northside Hospital is an icon in the metro Atlanta community and one of the best organization nationwide to work for.
job_title: Manager Clinical Services & Integration in Atlanta, GA
pros: Northside is the best hospital to work for in the metro Atlanta area because of the following reasons. 1)It puts patient's safety above everything else. 2) Employee satisfaction is evident throughout the Northside Hospital System; it is manifested by the very low turnover rate and the vast number of employees celebrating two to four decades of service. 3) Northside primarily promotes from within, and opportunity to move up to various positions in the hospital system is plentyful. Lastly, Northside Hospital is one of the few organizations nationwide that still offer a pension plan as part of their retirement package.
cons: The commute can be challenging depending on what part of the city or suburb you live in.

job_title: Staff RN III BMTU in Atlanta, GA
pros: Very welcoming and friendly centered work environment. Everyone goes out of their way to help you if you are lost. You have a very structured support system to guide you. Coming from another state, I was welcomed with open arms and since it was a new facility to me. I felt like I was coming from the ground up again. Everyone is very patient and giving me an equal opportunity to learn at my own pace. Very organized governing body. Great benefits and pay also.
cons: I came from out of state and my onboarding recruiter was slightly unorganized. Some paperwork slipped through the cracks. Honestly that's all I have to complain about.

pros: I’ve worked at Northside for more than  10 years now and I wouldn’t work anywhere else.  The work environment makes you appreciate your job and you are able to feel that you are valued as part of the team. There are also a lot of opportunities to improve your profession - they offer free education hours and hands on opportunities to continuously improve the nursing skills we give to our patients . Northside also recognizes every employee which makes you feel you are appreciated as an individual employee. The benefits and hourly rate is just an icing on a cake since you don’t really feel like you’re at work at all  when you love and enjoy your job and your work family.
cons: I can’t think of any downside

job_title: Manager, Cellular Therapy and Leukemia Program in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Northsides service excellence standards have always impressed me. Not just for what the expectations are, but also how they are followed through upon. The majority of employees I encounter live up to these standards daily, in both staffing and leadership roles. It allows for a warm and positive work experience.

My team knocks it out of the park when it comes to meeting these standards and I believe it's passed on through the excellent patient care they provide. Patients often pay compliments to the team and convey their thanks for the support they are given through a difficult time. The fact that the patient is always first in all things we do is one of the best parts of working in this healthcare system and in this program.
cons: I do not have any cons! I love working here.

pros:
A lot of good benefits , yearly reviews with possible raises, quality control, 
medical insurance , continous online classes
cons: They are expanding too quickly to keep up with theirselves:things get over looked and put off. You get told by some people certain things that never come to pass basically unkept promises.. staff spread too thin and no one doing anything about it. Under paid so far-grossly. Lunch time taken from your hohrs daily even if you dont take a lunch:such as working only 5 hours-30 minutes will be deducted wether you want it to or not. Not very good communication between different levels of management/staff.

pros: Great colleagues, excellent experience, support for continued education, benefits aren't bad.
cons: The NICU management needs a major overhaul.  A handful of the managers are excellent, but the rest are awful. Punitive, nit-picky, and non-supportive. There are very few opportunities for advancement and the folks with positions in leadership got those positions because of who they knew, not because of their own skill or leadership capability. They pay lip service to shared governance, and there is so much fighting and resentment between members of management that it's virtually impossible to make any changes for the better. Big Brother is Watching.

pros: Caring for the patients in the Maternity Unit
cons: Management is not supportive, and has poor communication skills when dealing with nurses and other managers working in the same unit. Nurses are told patient care is a priority, however, paper charting in such a large, busy hospital is extremely time consuming and takes away from patient care. Although Mother Baby nurses are in charge and responsible for the care of couplets, all infant charts, charting, pediatric visits, orders and communication take place in the nursery which is a separate area located away from the Mother Baby nurse. I feel the ability to be involved in this process has a negative effect on patient care. Many of the preceptors are unmotivated, and uninterested in the learners achievements. Managers are aware but turn a blind eye.

job_title: Lab Tech Assistant in Canton, GA
pros: Great pay.  Close nit culture of family. Management address issues promptly.
cons: Supervisor praises in private (rarely) and corrects in public. It's very humiliating for the target. The profanity level has improved thanks to management but still needs work. For those of us that don't smoke we miss out on all the breaks that the smokers get. There tends to be perverted conversation. You have to find a way to break free from the room. If someone has no problem with these things they'll be fine.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Canton, GA
pros: The kind, helpful staff is definitely a plus. I always feel supported when working my shifts. The management is more than willing to be flexible with my school schedule as I'm finishing pursuing my nursing degree. The overall work environment is positive and calming.
cons: The only con would be length of time you must stay with the company before qualifying for the tuition reimbursement program. It does make sense, though that they reserve this benefit for those employees who dedicate their loyalty through time to Northside.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: Good work culture, good benefits, generally lovely place to work, if you like the subject matter.
cons: Processes can be innumerable and impossible to keep up with. Management is either completely hands-off or overly micromanage-y.

pros: The Recruitment Team is very attentive and helpful throughout your hiring process. They give you insight on the next steps, what to expect and when, and they give you tips on how to.prepare to be your best for the interview and other future processes.
cons: The Human Resources aspect can be alittle confusing going in, because they don't go over in extreme detail about the Human Resources or payroll process to ensure you have a better understanding. It's more so you come to them, instead of them seeking you.

job_title: Clinical Development Specialist in Canton, GA
pros: As a current employee I could not be happier working with the Northside Hospital system.  I'm so proud to work with staff who truly care about their patients and I'm even prouder to work for a company who truly care about their staff.  The bonus for working at Northside, regardless of which hospital it is, is being a part of the community.  Northside supports it's community in so many different ways, from financial to hands on.  I feel honored to be a part of the Northside system.
cons: Because it is a large hospital, with so many employees at times it is tough to get things done.  For example, it took almost a month for me to get my VPN access.

review_title: Northside is a great place to work for, with opportunities for advancement.
pros: Salary, OT, incentive pay, each unit feels more like family, close knit coworkers
cons: Constantly understaffed, floating is a frequent occurrence and some units don't treat you as well as they treat their own, overworked, amount of charting is insane, never have enough PCTs, turnover rates are high, burnout is frequent

review_title: Good people on the floor, terrible management
pros: Pay, benefits, non-management people are nice, professional, and helpful.
cons: Management has no idea what they are doing and do not value employees over their work to cost ratio. Management has no qualms giving you impossible tasks and then getting mad at you for not being able to do them, nor do they have any qualms with loading you up with overtime, sometimes in excess of 40 hours of overtime a week, and then have the audacity to not understand when you want to take time off because you haven't seen your family in almost a week.

pros: Everyone I know feels lucky to have landed at Northside. We have all worked at other healthcare providers, and Northside is easily the best. Excellent Patient Care is our purpose, but Excellent Employee Care is how we get there. Salaries are competitive and benefits are above average, including an employer funded pension plan, which is very rare among hospital systems in Georgia. Northside also takes excellent care of their physicians. It is easy for us all to be on the same side. Many employees at all levels have been here for decades. The sonyou get here, the better off you will be.
cons: Most of us have brutal commutes during normal times, but it is worth it. Lately we have had a reprieve.

pros: Steady work. Flexible scheduling. Great team in my unit.
cons: Nurses are valued far higher than clerical and tech staff.

review_title: Fast Pace environment that people who learn fast and self start will thrive in.
job_title: Applications Analyst in Sandy Springs, Fulton, GA
pros: Pay is good. Flexible if you need to come in a little early or late. If your not in a office you have a Full Sized Cubical.
cons: No backfilling or advancement after a new Hospital wide EMR implimentation and while pending merger with another hospital system. Management seems to like to make uninformed decisions that sound good in theory but do not include the teams that will support the product so obvious issues are over looked.

review_title: New manager destroyed our department while director and HR just looked on.
pros: Before the new manager we had a wonderful department, a place where we could concentrate on patient care and safety.
cons:
This new managers primary objective is to have her ego elevated, she’s paranoid and vindictive. Created drama, gossip, animosity and then blamed others for the chaos she created.
Totally blindsided a director who used to be wonderful. 
More than 4 employees have quit and two are on FMLA leave due to this manager’s approach. Only five full time employees left of a team of 12 plus PRNs, who also lost their jobs thanks to her “leadership”.

pros: Awesome benefits and hours. I love the fact that PTO is easy to accrue and it carries over into the next year.
cons: You have to have PTO  to receive a day off.  A  few years ago you use to just be able to not get paid for that day. Also, holidays are not paid you must use PTO.  There is no cross training or growth, it is hard to move up in the company.

pros: Northside Hospital Cherokee is a great company to work for that really cares about their employees. Work- life balance is really important to me and this company will go above and beyond to try to meet your needs. I really enjoy my job and Northside Hospital Cherokee truly cares about patient care.
cons: In my line of work I have to take call and the staff is not many in numbers so employees do have to take more call than one would like. Not much room for growth if you are not a nurse.

pros: I began working as a hospitalist at Northside in 2000 and continue in that capacity. As the health system has grown it has remained true to its mission and has retained a "family feel."
cons: With the rapid growth of the system there has been some lag time in integrating new facilities.

review_title: Hospitality at its Finest: Northside Hospital
pros: I was greeted with a smile and a helping hand the second I walked through the doors of Northside.  As a new employee here, I felt welcomed and at home right away. The sense of belonging that this place provides weaves its way through the halls to patients, families, and staff. I am thankful to be part of such a wonderful organization that cares for the whole person.
cons: I cannot think of a con. When you find yourself in a place like Northside, you do not want to leave it.

review_title: Why I still work at NS
pros: Starting off as a new nurse here 10 years ago, I never felt alone in making decisions. There are so many resources to help new nurses. I feel that was a huge piece to my success at NS. I've been lucky to have supervisors and managers that have been so supportive over the years. We are a very busy hospital, so one will get a lot of experience in caring for patients.The benefits are great for my family. I have been given the opportunity to move up in ranks and have done so quickly throughout the years.
cons: Time and attendance can be challenging, especially if you have kids or you have a lot going on in your personal life.

review_title: Great place to work for a Career move.......
pros: I have enjoyed working for this company for several years. The merit raise each year are excellent and they also have a pension for there employees which most companies don't offer anymore.   This company is always expanding for the better which I think is a very positive outlook.
cons: If the overall employees of North side Hospital  could be offer a bonus at the end of the each fiscal year. I believe that could bring in more applicants to consider working for NSH.

job_title: Supply Chain Technician in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great insurance plans and competitive pay
cons: You have favoritism with certain employees, you are unable to check your time and attendance, very micromanaging, also to learn the job you have to be trained by someone who already has been at the job but if you do not know something and you need to know a task or a duty, the trainer acts like she does not want to show you the proper way. Poor communication and poor managerial skills.

review_title: Not what I thought Nursing would be like.
pros:
Demographic of employees
Pleasant facilities
Equipment available when needed
Location
cons:
Stress level
High patient turn over
Patient to nurse ratio (1:4 on step-down units)
Lack of managerial support
Terrible raises for nurses
Almost 0 guaranteed lunch break for nurses (if you want to leave on time at night, that is)

pros: Northside has been the best place for employment. When I felt I was not being challenged at my old job (within Northside), HR and my manager all worked together with me to find what area would suit me best. I now work on a Pulmonary/Thoracic Stepdown ICU and love it.  Northside does a great job of healthy nurse:patient ratios. Medsurg 3:1 or 4:1, Critical care 2:1 or 3:1. Northside is for you. We have great benefits. Pay that is competitive if not better to other hospitals in the area. Living in Atlanta I always say I would never work for another hospital.
cons: May not have specific trauma or other specialties one desires. Not all electronic charting, but moving that way!

review_title: I truly believe that NH is a great place to work!
pros:
NH has some of the best physicians available.  We are current with state of the art technology and continually growing with services and what we can offer our patients.
The staff/leadership team are like my 2nd family making coming to work something I look forward to!  There is a huge emphasis on providing the best patient care we can.  Many opportunities for growth.
cons: Parking can be challenging some days but it is free to employees and a new garage is currently under construction!

job_title: Physician Denial Management Spec in Atlanta, GA
pros: I work on a team with wonderful co-workers, we get along very well and my direct supervisor is awesome.  People are nice and polite to each other. We have good benefits and are able to take time off without any hassle.
cons: My commute is longer since we moved to a new building, I have to take expressway now. Management could do a better job of communicating regarding new policies and workflow. New dress code is coming, I have been casual for so long.  It would be nice if I could work from home some days, I need a better work/life balance.

review_title: Northside Hospital is an Amazing Place to Work
job_title: Director, Value Based Clinical Care in Roswell, GA
pros: Northside treats its employees as family. All my experiences with leadership have been very supportive and they really encourage employees on upward mobility throughout the system. They prefer to hire from within if possible which gives employees many opportunities for advancement. The employee benefits are fantastic.
cons: We have become very large and as with many large entities, it can take a longer time to get new programs rolled out. Outdated telecommunications directories. There needs to be a focus every year to keep these updated as we continue to grow.

review_title: You’ve tried the rest now come work for the best!
pros: Amazing place to work! Patient focused with resources to ensure that all families have a positive experience while they are with us. Working here gives you celebrity status in the community! When you wear the Northside brand, people will recognize you and make a point to tell you their story ... the great experience not only that they have had but everyone in their family and their friends have had. A great since of pride for where you work. One of the only healthcare facilities that offers a pension as a part of the benefits package.
cons: I have no cons to post.

review_title: No Leadership, No Vision, No employee appreciation
pros: Has a good reputation for baby deliveries
cons:
Nurses are not appreciated.  Nurses week was celebrated on Friday (last day of the week) at 2pm, with a Popsicle.

There is NOT a chief nursing officer or a chief medical officer.  1 out of 10 employees could point out CEO/CFO in a line up.  Three campuses that only share the Northside name.  

Most physicians are community physicians and therefore are not invested in making the hospital better.

The electronic medical record is a little better than HORRIBLE.  

There is high turnover and high patient to nurse ratios.  Pay is decent for new hires but very few raises for employees that have been with the company for any length of time.

Managers get promoted not on qualifications but rather they have been in a position for a long time.

pros:
I love Northside! Until I was hired at Northside, I didn't think there was a way to advance without a degree in the medical profession. I have been promoted twice in the two years and its all because Northside recognizes people's hard work and dedication. 
I love Northside and fully plan on retiring from this organization! 
Northside is dedicated to service excellence to patients, their family members, and  staff member. When I'm here I feel like an integral part of a team and a culture. There is always a 5k, bake sale, and volunteer opportunities.
cons: Every employee needs to have a work email address. It would help distribute information more efficiently.

pros: I worked at Northside for a total of 7 yrs...in that time I gained my Bachelors degree in business as well as my Masters Degree because I wanted to grow with the company...I developed a special bond there and family..I had both my children there..loved my job...
cons: When I wanted to grow...I was never given the chance...no room for growth at all unless you know the right people.. A lot of favoritism...I applied for several positions and never was given a chance...

pros: It’s a new hospital, very clean and well laid out
cons: Crayola academy. Nurses are recognized for their ability to woo pts and each other with trinkets, flowers, hairdressing ability, and hospitality. Pts insurance companies are paying top dollar for a spa treatment and to be placed on a thrown and while that’s nice and cozy someone has to review the data, make proper assessments and implement clinically appropriate treatment. If that’s you, I’m sorry. U will be frowned on for being strong and not having the time to pillow fluff and lay candy down. Nobody will be thankful that u figured out the actual problem. There’s no room for experience and clinical excellence if it gets in the way of placation and royalty.

job_title: Director of Population Health in Lawrenceville, GA
pros: Northside is financially sound, which provides security to its employees. In my immediate department, the teams are collaborative with making decisions and pursuing change. Immediate governance does have interdisciplinary leadership. Immediate leadership is reasonable and fair in expectations.
cons: The ambulatory environment is not as structured as inpatient. Operations and workflows could be better standardized across technology and processes. Governance does not include physician leadership .

job_title: Patient Access Supervisor in Cumming, GA
pros: Excellent team atmosphere and exceptional leadership. Even before I became a member of this leadership team, I knew that they/we are Northside's most valuable and most unique asset. You just can't find a more supportive, nurturing and understanding group of leaders anywhere else.
cons: It's easy to get burned out.  NSH is very budget-conscious so there are hiring freezes every year and between holiday vacations, refusal to allow overtime, and generally being short-staffed, myself and my team are exhausted.  I love what I do, so it's worth it, but it can make me feel at times that we as employees are forgotten about.

review_title: I have been treated well at Northside and this is my second time working there.
pros:
pay is above average.
most people are friendly and helpful.
opportunities for growth and development.
some of the best doctors work there.
cafeteria food is excellent.
cons:
job security is low.
need more staff for workload. 
most staff are overloaded/overwhelmed with work to keep up with standards.
high staff injury/illnesses due to understaffed departments.

pros: Comfortable work environment, good nurses, very good consultant support, interesting mix of patient cases, very competitive benefits package (including pension plan, as well as 457 and 403b)
cons: Scheduling in our group seems disorganized and haphazard; no provision for surges in patient census; computerized order entry is dismal and we still do handwritten progress notes; administrative power structure is completely inscrutable though they are generally benevolent.

pros: Great company with great employees who truly care, and go above and beyond to delivering very high-quality care.  Speaking as an employee and also a patient who had surgery at Northside before I worked here, my experience with  everyone was amazing.  The RNs, techs and OR team was superb.  It made me want to work here.
cons: Parking at the Atlanta campus is a little rough right now, but a new deck is under construction to add more parking.

review_title: Great hospital and great place to work
pros: I love working for a company that I can be proud of.   The growth of our services in the community and our wonderful reputation means a lot to me.   The focus is on the patient and providing the best care possible and decisions are made with the highest ethical standards.
